nfoscarini wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> Sorry for asking some simple questions, but I can't find the answers
> anywhere. If there are answers posted somewhere (i.e. a Wiki) please
> direct me there, but the Wiki on the Heritrix website didn't seem to
> provide the answers I'm looking for.
> 
> 1) How can you control the page request speed of Heritrix. I performed
> one crawl that was requesting HTML pages from a server at 1.1 page per
> second. Which I think is to heavy a load on a web server.

Look in the settings for anything with 'delay' in it. Our default 
profiles include a minimum 2000ms delay before releasing another URI 
from the same host-based queue -- but if many hostnames are served from 
the same IP you could see faster visits in practice.

> 2) I see in the finished crawler report stats on images (JPG, GIF,
> etc. etc). Is Heritrix downloading images while it's crawling, and if
> so how do I disable that.

Yes, the crawler archives all file types by default. See this FAQ (and 
also search the list) for ideas on limiting the crawler to text only:

http://crawler.archive.org/faq.html#midfetch

(That technique will need some slight updating to work in latest 
DecideRule-rather-than-Filter-based releases -- you can also search the 
list archives for relevant discussion.

Given how common this need is, I really wish it were easier. However, 
the Internet Archive and its primary partners never crawl this way -- we 
always want images -- so any change here is more likely to come from an 
outside contribution.

> 3) I'm interested in archiving HTML that links to text files of the
> extension ".ms". How can I generate a report of HTML pages that
> contain those links? I also want to archive those .MS files.

You could postprocess the ARCs to find such pages. Or write your own 
Processor that checks for such links and affects followup crawling -- 
for example something that would go after Extractors and discard 
pages/links not of interest before they are written or their outbound 
links rescheduled with the Frontier.

> 4) Does anyone have Heritrix running on a network with multiple
> machines working on the same crawl job. Is this even possible?

Yes, crudely with manual splitting of the URI space. We've split jobs 
over as many as 6 machines at IA; we've heard of others splitting over 
as many as 8. Search the list archives for ["distributed crawler"] for 
some discussion & tips.

- Gordon @ IA
